item.title: India Ink: Dutch Man Confesses to Killing British Woman in Kashmir, Police Say
item.description: Attacker blamed influence of cannabis in part for killing, police said
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Journalists and policemen stand outside a houseboat where a female British tourist was found dead Saturday, on the Dal Lake in Srinagar.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Europe Doesn’t Trust Its Politicians. What’s the Alternative?
item.description: Politicians are accustomed to taking the blame when things go wrong. Europe’s economic crisis is, however, provoking a wider backlash against political leaders seen as failing to practice what they preach.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Anti-eviction protestors in Madrid on Wednesday.

item.title: From China, a Call to Avoid ‘Chaos for Selfish Gain’
item.description: As North Korea’s ally, China has been discomfited by the behavior of the North Korean leader but has refrained from signaling any course of action.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Saudis Delay Measure Affecting Foreign Workers
item.description: Stricter enforcement of laws on foreign workers raises fears of hardship in countries like Egypt and Yemen, which rely on remittances from its workers in Saudi Arabia.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:description: Marchers in Sana, Yemen, protested Saudi Arabia’s recent deportation of many Yemeni workers.

item.title: South Korea Expects Missile Launch by North
item.description: Tensions on the Korea peninsula remain high with a spokesman in Seoul saying the South expected a missile launch later this week.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: 5 Die in Year’s Worst Attack on U.S. in Afghanistan
item.description: A suicide bomb killed three American soldiers and two American civilians, including a 25-year-old State Department Foreign Service officer.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Afghan soldiers rushed to the scene of a car bombing in Qalat, Afghanistan. Another American was killed in eastern Afghanistan.

item.title: India Ink: Newswallah: Long Reads Edition
item.description: Best of long-form journalism this week.
item.dc:creator: By SRUTHI GOTTIPATI

item.title: Kerry Moves to Help Turkey and Israel to Restore Ties
item.description: The ties of Turkey and Israel have been frozen since 2010, but Secretary of State John Kerry is to meet with Turkey’s premier to discuss an agreement between the nations.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: Rally Demands Anti-Blasphemy Laws in Bangladesh
item.description: The group singled out bloggers who have called for the death penalty for those found guilty of war crimes during the 1971 war for independence.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Amid heightened security in Dhaka, Bangladesh, on Saturday, advocates demanded that the authorities enact a blasphemy law to punish those who insult Islam.

item.title: Afghan Suicide Bomber Kills 5 Americans
item.description: A suicide bomb killed three American soldiers and two American civilians, including a State Department Foreign Service officer.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Edith Schaeffer, 98, Dies; Defined Christian Values
item.description: Mrs. Schaeffer wrote books describing women’s domestic role in an increasingly secular world, and with her husband, founded the Christian commune L’Abri.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:description: Edith Schaeffer with her husband, Francis Schaeffer, in 1970 in Switzerland, where they founded L’Abri, a Christian commune.

item.title: Rumors About Uzbekistan Leader’s Health Set Off Succession Debate
item.description: Disputed reports about the health of President Islam Karimov, who has ruled for more than two decades, have underscored the uncertain politics of succession in Uzbekistan.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: President Islam Karimov’s oldest daughter, Gulnara Karimova, is seen as a possible successor.

item.title: Tensions With North Korea Unsettle South Korean Economy
item.description: The Seoul stock market fell Friday, and General Motors said it was making contingency plans for its workers amid a torrent of threats from North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Currency dealers in Seoul last week. South Korea’s main stock index closed at a low on Friday.

item.title: Syrian War Devastates Ancient Sites
item.description: Syria’s archaeological heritage, which has yet to be fully studied, is imperiled by threats ranging from outright destruction to opportunistic treasure hunters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Remains of the ancient city of Ebla. Its excavation has offered many insights into early Syrian civilization, but war is taking a toll on the site, like many others here.

item.title: WORLD: Destroying Syria's Past
item.description: Across Syria, the country’s archaeological heritage is imperiled by war, facing threats that range from outright destruction by ordnance to opportunistic digging by grave diggers and treasure hunters.

item.title: Nuclear Talks With Iran End Without Accord
item.description: The futility was certain to arouse renewed alarm, particularly from Israel, which had tempered its threats of a military strike in deference to diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Catherine Ashton of the European Union on Saturday with her chief spokesman, Michael Mann.

item.title: Japan Nuclear Plant Leaks Radioactive Water
item.description: A Fukushima Daiichi storage pool appeared to have lost almost 32,000 gallons, and thousands more could seep out before it can be pumped dry.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Egyptian Muslims and Christians in Fatal Clash Near Cairo
item.description: Security officials said five people died and eight were wounded in violence in the town of Khusus.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Brazil Opens Inquiry Into Claims of Wrongdoing by Ex-President
item.description: The move by the Public Ministry is thought to be the first time that former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva has been directly investigated in connection to the scheme.
item.category: Dirceu de Oliveira e Silva, Jose
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Myanmar Grapples With Ethnic Tensions
item.description: Analysts are divided on what deteriorating relations between the Kachin people and the country’s government mean for overall moves toward democracy and economic liberalization.

item.title: Royals in Spain Set for Disclosures
item.description: A new transparency law being negotiated in Parliament would impose greater disclosures and controls on financial assets of politicians and civil servants.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Rise of the Predators: Origins of C.I.A.’s Not-So-Secret Drone War in Pakistan
item.description: The C.I.A.’s covert drone war in Pakistan began with the 2004 killing of a Pashtun militant, the result of a secret deal that was a turning point in the agency’s fight against terrorism.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: Nek Muhammad, center, was a Pashtun militant who was killed in 2004, in the first C.I.A. drone strike in Pakistan.

item.title: Builders Arrested in India After Scores Die in Collapse
item.description: The police in Mumbai, India, arrested two builders after a half-finished residential structure collapsed, killing at least 72 people.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Nelson Mandela Released From Hospital
item.description: Nelson Mandela, the 94-year-old former president of South Africa, was released from a hospital in Johannesburg after treatment for pneumonia.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Syrian Airstrikes Kill at Least 5 in Aleppo
item.description: Government forces also battled rebels in a town outside Damascus, the capital.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
